    • ProDy Project

      ProDy is a free and open-source Python package for protein sequence, structure, and dynamics analysis. It is designed as a flexible and responsive API suitable for interactive usage, and comes with several command line applications.

      How to Use ProDy

      To learn how to use ProDy you may start from the Tutorial or one of the detailed usage Examples. You can also browse the new front page and discover brand new sequence evolution analysis features!

      Develop with ProDy

      You can use ProDy for developing or prototyping new applications. Flexible and fully documented ProDy API is being continuously improved and tested with over 1,800 documentation and unit tests. See the API Reference and what's new.

      References

      ProDy: Protein Dynamics Inferred from Theory and Experiments Bakan A, Meireles LM, Bahar I 2011 Bioinformatics 27(11):1575-1577

      Getting ProDy

      See Getting ProDy for installing instructions, or install it with: 

      $ easy_install -U ProDy

      E-mail Group

      To stay up to date, join the ProDy-news Google group (one e-mail per release):

      Issue Tracker

      For suggestions, problems, and feature requests open an issue at the Bitbucket tracker.

    • Sequence Evolution

      ProDy is a free and open-source Python package for analysis and modeling of protein structural dynamics. It allows for efficient analysis of large datasets and is suitable for development or prototyping of structure-based analysis and modeling software.

    • Protein Structure

      ProDy is a free and open-source Python package for analysis and modeling of protein structural dynamics. It allows for efficient analysis of large datasets and is suitable for development or prototyping of structure-based analysis and modeling software.

    • Protein Dynamics

      ProDy is a free and open-source Python package for analysis and modeling of protein structural dynamics. It allows for efficient analysis of large datasets and is suitable for development or prototyping of structure-based analysis and modeling software.

    • Normal Mode Wizard

      Normal Mode Wizard (NMWiz) is a VMD plugin designed for visual comparative analysis of normal mode data, i.e. modes may come from principal component, essential dynamics, normal mode analysis or may be any vector describing a molecular motion.

      NMWiz allows you to:

      • perform ANM, GNM, and PCA/EDA calculations
      • draw customizable normal modes arrows
      • make animations (sample conformations)
      • make interactive square-fluctuations plots
      • compare two structures and draw deformation arrows

      See NMWiz Tutorial or NMWiz documentation for usage details. You can input normal mode data to NMWiz in NMD Format or any other format recognized by VMD.

    • Applications

      ProDy is a free and open-source Python package for analysis and modeling of protein structural dynamics. It allows for efficient analysis of large datasets and is suitable for development or prototyping of structure-based analysis and modeling software.

    • Publications¶

      Using ProDy¶

      1. The intrinsic dynamics of enzymes plays a dominant role in determining the structural changes induced upon inhibitor binding Bakan A, Bahar I 2009 Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 106(34):14349-14354
      2. Computational Generation of Inhibitor-Bound Conformers of P38 MAP Kinase and Comparison with Experiments Bakan A, Bahar I 2011 Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing 16:181-192
      3. ProDy: Protein Dynamics Inferred from Theory and Experiments Bakan A, Meireles LM, Bahar I 2011 Bioinformatics 27(11):1575-1577
      4. Pre-existing soft modes of motion uniquely defined by native contact topology facilitate ligand binding to proteins Meireles L, Gur M, Bakan A, Bahar I 2011 Protein Science 10(20):1645-1658

      Servers¶

      • Principal component analysis of native ensembles of biomolecular structures (PCA_NEST): insights into functional dynamics
        Yang LW, Eyal E, Bahar I, Kitao A
        2009 Bioinformatics 25:606-614

        Go to PCA_NEST

      • Anisotropic network model: systematic evaluation and a new web interface
        Eyal E, Yang LW, Bahar I
        2006 Bioinformatics 22:2619-27.

        Go to ANM Server

      • oGNM: online computation of structural dynamics using the Gaussian Network Model
        Yang LW, Rader AJ, Liu X, Jursa CJ, Chen SC, Karimi HA, Bahar I
        2006 Nucleic Acids Res 34:W24-31

        Go to oGNM Server

      • iGNM: A Database of Protein Functional Motions Based on Gaussian Network Model
        Yang LW, Liu X, Jursa CJ, Holliman M, Rader AJ, Karimi HA, Bahar I
        2005 Bioinformatics 21:2978-2987

        Go to iGNM database

    • Acknowledgments¶

      People¶

      Lidio Meireles provided insightful comments on the design of ProDy classes and modules, and contributed to the development of early versions of ProDy Commands for automated tasks.

      Funding¶

      Support from NIH grants 1R01GM099738-01 (current) and 1R01GM086238-01 for development and maintenance of ProDy is acknowledged by Ivet Bahar.

      Community¶

      ProDy makes use of the following great software developed by the open source community:

      • Pyparsing for the sophisticated atom selection grammar.
      • Biopython KDTree package and pairwise2 module.
      • Numpy for speed and flexibility in almost all major functionality.
      • Finally, ProDy can benefit from Scipy and Matplotlib packages.
